questions.text: All of the following used to prevent Frey's syndrome except
questions.solution: Frey's syndrome can be prevented by raising a thicker skin flap during surgery, or by placing a Temporalis myocutaneous flap over the parotid bed to avoid regeneration reaching the skin and also giving SMAS (Superficial Muscle Aponeurotic System) present in face. Aluminium Chloride is an anti perspirant used in the treatment of Frey's.

choices.text: Responding Evidence of Chemotherapy In Soft tissue Tumors
Response Evaluation Criteria In Soft tissue Tumors
Reactive Evidence Criteria in Solid Tumors
Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors

questions.text: RECIST criteria is
questions.solution: RECIST - Response Evaluation Criteria In Solid Tumors

questions.text: 48 male presented to the OPD with painless progressive Swelling as shown in the picture below for past 4 months. There is visible pulsations seen over the swelling. There is no cough impulse and swelling is mobile in both directions. Patient has ptosis, miosis on the left side. Diagnosis?
questions.solution: In the question, I have told there is visible pulsation over the swelling in the lateral neck and not the swelling is pulsatile, this rules out carotid aneurysm. I have also said that the swelling is mobile in all directions, this rules out carotid body tumor which is mobile only in horizontal direction and not vertically {this is called Fontaine sign} and although branchial cyst will be a possibility yet it does not cause Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: Vismodegib is recently approved for use in
questions.solution: Vismodegib was recently approved for use in advanced or metastatic BCC and works by targeting SMO (SMOOTHENED Protein) gain-of-function mutations within the hedgehog pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an Oncologic Surgical Emergency?

choices.text: Preoperative embolization is required for resection planned in Shamblin I
Hypoglossal nerve is commonly injured during Surgery
Superior laryngeal nerve is most commonly injured during Surgery

questions.text: 55 female presented with a swelling in the right side of the neck in Level II region. CT angiography is done which shows this characteristic picture. What is false regarding the management of this condition?
questions.solution: CT angiography shows Lyre sign suggestive of Carotid body tumor, which is neuroendocrine tumor with high vascularity from external carotid, so FNA or biopsy is contraindicated. Shamblin classification is Type I, II & III depends on the extend of resectablility and relationship to carotid vessesl, where Type I is easily resectable. Type II and III requires preoperative embolization to shrink the tumor and facilitate safe surgery. Superior laryngeal, Hypoglossal nerve are commonly injured; next in line is Vagus nerve.

choices.text: FNA of the node followed by Imaging of Head and neck preferably MRI
Panendoscopy should be done if primary is not identified.
If no tumor identified, standard treatment is Radical Neck Dissection and postoperative RT
Survival rates for Metastatic adenocarcinoma is better than squamous secondaries

questions.text: Regarding the management of Secondaries neck, FALSE statement is
questions.solution:
Protocol in Secondary Neck with unknown Primary:

  1. FNAC of Node
  2. Imaging - CT or MRI
  3. Pan endoscopy
  4. Blind Biopsy

Pan endoscopy - Nasopharyngoscopy, Direct Laryngoscopy, Esophagoscopy, (may add bronchoscopy if needed)

Blind Biopsy - Fossa of Rosenmuller, lateral Pharyngeal wall, Pyriform fossa, Base of tongue, Subglottis

If primary is not identified we will go for RND and Post op RT.

Secondaries Left neck with FNA: Type of Secondary

  • For adeno carcinomatous deposits, Thyroid malignancies, salivary gland tumors, lung and breast cancers are possibility
  • For squamous cell cancers of head and neck like oral cavity, oropharynx and hypopharyngeal cancers.

Survival rates for Metastatic Squamous is better than Adenocancer secondaries

questions.text: 40 male presented with 2cm black pigmented ulcerated lesion in the back, with ABCD signs of melanoma. Next step in the line of management is
questions.solution: Lesions suspicious of malignant melanoma if the lesion is small, can undergo excision biopsy with 1-2 mm margins to allow future sentinel node mapping to stage the Nodal staging. Punch biopsy can also be done, but it should not be taken from the edge of the lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following Extremity sarcomas can go for ahead for primary surgery directly without Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy
questions.solution:
There are certain soft tissue sarcomas which should be given Neoadjuvant chemotherapy before waiting for surgery.

They are

  1. Rhabdomyosarcoma
  2. Ewings sarcoma
  3. Synovial sarcoma
  4. Pleomorphic liposarcoma

questions.text: The treatment shown below is used in which of the following situations?
questions.solution: The image shown is Isolated Limb infusion or Hyperthermic Isolated Limp Perfusion with chemotherapeutic agent to prevent systemic toxicity and enhance the chemotherapeutic effect by cannulating the major vessels of the involved limb and applying tourniquet proximally to prevent systemic entry. It is used in Intransit metastases of Malignant melanoma.

questions.text: Regarding BRCA mutations, False statement is
questions.solution:
BRCA 1 (45%) 17q21

Breast Cancer 60 - 85%

Ovarian Cancer 15 - 40%

Prostate, Bone, Colon and Liver cancers

Poorly differentiated, Triple Negative (Hormone receptor negative)

Bilateral or multifocal

Early age of onset

questions.text: BCS is possible in which of the following?
questions.solution:
BCS cannot be done in T4 lesions (skin or chest wall involvement) or Fixed axillary nodes (N2). So BCD options ruled out.

T3N1 can still be a possibility, if the patient wants to conserve her breast. In such conditions, Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy is given which shrinks the size of the tumor thereby helps in doing BCS.

This is the only LABC where BCS is still a possibility in patients who have complete response to chemotherapy and who really needs to conserve breast.

questions.text: What is the ideal management of a young patient with Stage I breast cancer?
questions.solution: For any stage of Breast Cancer, it is multimodality management. Surgery + Chemotherapy + Radiotherapy + Hormonal therapy.

questions.text: 45 female with hard breast lump of size 6x5cm in right upper outer quadrant with overlying peau'd orange appearance and multiple mobile axillary nodes of size 2cm palpable. No evidence of distant metastases made out clinically. What is the Staging?
questions.solution: Breast lump of any size with peau'd orange is T4b and multiple mobile axillary nodes is N1 and clinically no metastases (M0) and it belongs to Stage IIIB

choices.text: It is common among lactating mothers
On IHC studies, it stains positive for CEA
It is a case of Eczema, so should be referred to dermatologist

questions.text: 40 female presented to the Surgery OPD with complaints of itching and scaly eruption over the Right breast for the past 6 months. No underlying lump on examination. The inspection is shown in this picture. True statement from the following is
questions.solution:
The condition is Paget's disease of Breast.

It is Unilateral, and not usually itchy. It is common in elderly women and nipple and areola will be destroyed in most instances.

Diagnosis is established by Scrape cytology or skin biopsy which demonstrates Paget's cells. IHC studies stain positive for CEA

choices.text: She is likely to have a breast abscess
Skin biopsy is often essential to make the diagnosis
This is hyperpigmentation of the breast due to pregnancy

questions.text: 24 year female came with sudden onset of breast engorgement for the past 3 months. She has pain over the past 1 week. She has stopped breast feeding some 2 months ago. On inspection, the following findings are seen. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution: This female is having breast enlargement with edema and peau'd orange appearance involving almost the entire circumference. Patient is a young post natal mother all these clues, favours towards a diagnosis of Inflammatory Breast Carcinoma, an aggressive condition where there is tumor cells invading the dermal lymphatics causing obstruction and edema and peau'd orange appearance involving more than one-third of the breast. Diagnosis is by Skin biopsy where dermal lymphatic invasion is pathognomic. Lymph node metastases occur in 75% and distant metastases occur in 25% at presentation.

questions.text: Patient with MEN 2B RET protooncogene mutation should undergo total thyroidectomy within
questions.solution: Surgery for Prophylactic Total thyroidectomy should be done within 1 year in MEN2B

questions.text: 4D's Diarrhea, Dermatitis, DVT and depression is seen with
questions.solution:
Glucagonoma clinical features include 4 'D's

Dermatitis

Diarrhea

Deep vein thrombosis

Depression

choices.text: Superior from 4th and inferior from 3rd branchial pouch

questions.text: Parathyroid embryology True is
questions.solution:
Superior parathyroid - from 4th branchial pouch

Inferior parathyroid from 3rd branchial pouch

questions.text: Ultrasonographical features of Thyroid malignancy, all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Sonographical Features of Malignancy in a thyroid nodule are

  • Solid nodule with halo
  • Irregular margins
  • Hypoechogenicity
  • Microcalcifications
  • Intranodular vascularity
  • Tall than wide

questions.text: A 60 year male presented with jaundice, pale stools, dark urine and mass in the Epigastric region. Which of the following diagnosis is unlikely?
questions.solution: Patient with mass in epigastric region and obstructive jaundice. Chronic cholecystitis is not a possibility as the gallbladder is shrunken and cannot cause GB distension. (Courvoisier's law)

questions.text: All are indications for Prophylactic Cholecystectomy except
questions.solution:
Prophylactic cholecystectomy is done in

During Ladd's procedure, Prophylactic appendicectomy is done to avoid confusion in future left iliac fossa pain as all the colon will be on left and small bowel will be on right.

choices.text: Open Cholecystectomy and Roux en Y Choledochojejunostomy
Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy followed by ERCP and Metal Stenting

questions.text: 40 female presented to the hospital with obstructive jaundice. On Evaluation with USG revealed Gall stones and CBD and IHBR dilatation. MRCP done which showed CBD dilatation 2cm with multiple distal stones and Stricture. The Surgeon wants to follow up the patient with ERCP in case the patients recurs with similar complaints. What will be the best management of choice?
questions.solution: For multiple CBD stones and stricture with dilated CBD, the ideal procedure must be Some Biliary Drainage. The best procedure for drainage will be Roux en Y Choledochojejunostomy. But in this case, Choledochoduodenostomy will be the choice of procedure which has the advantage of future ERCP follow up.

questions.text: Most common type of Choledochal Cyst
questions.solution: Alonso-Lej/Todani classification of Choledochal cyst

questions.text: Pancreatic cancer has the highest association with
questions.solution: Hereditary Risk factors

choices.text: It is an ERCP picture showing CBD stone & Biliary dilatation
It is an ERCP picture showing Biliary and Pancreatic duct dilatation
It is an MRCP picture showing CBD stone & Biliary dilatation
It is an MRCP picture showing growth in Common bile duct and proximal dilatation

questions.text: What of the following statements is true regarding the image shown below?
questions.solution: Obviously it's an MRCP picture. If it's an ERCP picture, it will be of X ray quality and you can view the Side viewing scope in each picture. You can see the Gall bladder distension, all Intrahepatic biliary radicles being dilated. There is massive dilatation of the Distal CBD with an obvious filling defect. To differentiate between a stone and a growth is, the stone creates a border which is semilunar.

questions.text: D'Edigio classification is used for
questions.solution: D'Edigio classification is used for Pancreatic Pseudocysts

questions.text: Non visualization of gallbladder in hepatic scintigraphy is seen in
questions.solution: HIDA scan is done to rule out obstruction of cystic duct.  HIDA cannot enter when the cystic duct is blocked. So, hence in acute cholecystitis, gall bladder cannot be visualized.

questions.text: In a patient with pyogenic liver abscess all the following are true except
questions.solution: Pyogenic Liver abscess most commonly occurs through infection from the biliary tract and usually occurs in elderly, more common with alcohol use and diabetics. It is more common in right liver and Jaundice is a common association.

questions.text: Most common complication following Whipple procedure is

choices.text: Magistral type is branching occurring at the hilum
The classification is given by Michels
There are superior, middle and inferior polar arteries

questions.text: Regarding Splenic vasculature, False statement is
questions.solution:
Regarding Splenic vasculature, Variation is given by Michels

  1. Distributed type - most common 70%, where branching occurs more proximally
  2. Magistral type - 30%, branching occurs at the hilum

Branches traditionally Superior and inferior polar artery (No Middle Polar) - further divides to Superior, middle and inferior terminal arteries.


A is Distributive Type

B is Magistral type

choices.text: Dorsal pancreatic duct drains into major papilla
It is present in 10% of individuals
Common bile duct drains into minor papilla
Ventral pancreatic duct drains into minor papilla

questions.text: Pancreas divisum - True statement is
questions.solution: Pancreas divisum is an embryological abnormality due to failure of dorsal and ventral ducts to fuse thereby causing ventral pancreatic duct and common bile duct to drain into major papilla and dorsal pancreatic duct to drain into minor papilla and is seen in 10 % of the population.

questions.text: 45 female underwent Laparoscopic cholecystectomy for chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis and HPE shows Gall bladder adenocarcinoma confined to mucosa alone, What is the appropriate management in this situation?
questions.solution: Lap cholecystectomy for Chronic cholecystitis, HPE turned out to be Gall bladder cancer limited to mucosa alone, T1a. In such cases, No further surgery is needed. Excision of port sites are not advocated nowadays, as port site infiltration is considered metastatic disease.

choices.text: Klatskin tumor is the most common
Use of OCP has an association with development of cholangiocarcinoma
Primary sclerosing cholangitis usually affects perihilar region

questions.text: Regarding cholangiocarcinoma, False statement is
questions.solution: Primary sclerosing cholangitis can affect both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts and not specifically peri hilar region. Perihilar cholangiocarcinoma or Klatskin tumor is the most common type

choices.text: 70% of cases occur by hematogenous spread
One third of cases in adults and children are multilocular
Fungal abscess is common in immunocompromised individuals
Unilocular abscess can be managed by percutaneous drainage and IV antibiotics

questions.text: All are true regarding splenic abscess EXCEPT
questions.solution: Splenic abscess result from hematogenous spread in 70% of patients. Unilocular abscess treated by Percutaneous drainage. Fungal abscess common with immunocompromised. In one third of adults, abscess is multilocular and in one third of children, it is unilocular

questions.text: Which of the following is an Excision procedure for Lymphedema?
questions.solution:
• Reconstructive
    • When Distal lymphatics good - Lymphovenous shunt (Neibulowitz)
    • When atrophic or damaged,
      • Omental flap (Gillies operation)
      • Enteromesenteric bridge (Kinmonth operation)
  • Excisional - Charles, Homans, Sistrunk, Thompson

questions.text: All of the following procedures are useful in Perforator incompetence except
What is the criteria most commonly used to define Buerger's disease?
What's the use of this instrument?
questions.solution:
The picture shows a Fogarty Embolectomy catheter.

It is a single lumen balloon tipped catheter comes in various sizes based on the length and diameter of the balloon with color codes

Varies from 2Fr to 7 Fr.

questions.text: Scores used to predict DVT include
questions.solution:
Scores used to predict DVT - Roger's score and Caprini score

Modified well's score is used in DVT also. Correct answer is a, b, c all.

Another Score used to predict Pulmonary embolism - Modified Wells score

questions.text: C4b in CEAP classification include
questions.solution:
CEAP classification - (C - Clinical)

C 0 - No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C 1 - Telengiectasia or thread veins

C2 - Varicose veins

C3 - Edema of the Lower limb

C4a - Hyperpigmentation, Eczema

C4b - Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C5 - Healed ulceration

C 6 - Active ulceration

choices.text: Presents with headache but no tumor

questions.text: False statement regarding Idiopathic intracranial hypertension is
questions.solution: This condition presents with features of raised ICP without an underlying tumour, explaining the old terms for the condition, pseudotumourcerebri or benign intracranial hypertension. This description is misleading, since Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension can progress rapidly to blindness.The patient, typically a young overweight female, describes a headache typical of raised pressure, and visual deterioration. Examination may reveal papilloedema, and occasionally cranial nerve palsies. Imaging is unremarkable, but lumbar puncture demonstrates a raised opening pressure >25 mmHg.

questions.text: A 60 male presented with history of severe headache admitted in ED, now became drowsy and confused. His Hunt Hess Clinical grade is
questions.solution: Hunt Hess grade is used in patients with subarachnoid hemorrhage to predict the neurological outcome and mortality.

questions.text: Cause of Obstructive Hydrocephalus is
questions.solution:
Obstructive Hydrocephalus is termed when the CSF from the ventricles is prevented from communicating into subarachnoid space. Causes will be Brain tumors causing aqueductal stenosis, Chairi I and II malformation

Communicating hydrocephalus caused by defective absorption (post hemorrhagic, post stroke, post infective, post neurosurgery)

questions.text: This picture depicts which phenomenon?
questions.solution: Monro-Kellie Doctrine states "Any increase in the volume of intracranial contents (from blood or edema) results in an elevation of Intracranial pressure (ICP) with an associated decrease in the volume of other tissues, such as the brain parenchyma and cerebrospinal fluid.

choices.text: Surgical repair should be done within 48 hours or birth

questions.text: False statement regarding Myelomeningocele is
questions.solution: Myelomeningocele is the most common type of spina bifida aperta. It is associated with Chiari II malformation and also hydrocephalus. Surgical repair is indicated within 48 hours of life

questions.text: All of the following formula are used in fluid resuscitation in burns except
questions.solution:
Burns formula for resuscitation

  1. Parkland formula (for crystalloids)
  2. Muir and Barclay formula (colloids)
  3. Galveston formula (in children)

Berkow formula, Wallace rule of nine, Lund and browder chart are to measure the burnt surface area.

questions.text: Which of the following drug penetrates Eschar in Burns?
questions.solution:
Most commonly used Antimicrobial salve is 1% silver sulphadiazine. It has advantage of no pain, easy to apply. But has disadvantage of not able to penetrate eschar and not effective against pseudomonas.

Mafenide acetate has the advantage of penetrating eschar and active against pseudomonas but is associated with extreme pain and metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: Full thickness graft has more secondary contraction
Primary contraction is due to elastin

questions.text: True statement of the following is
questions.solution:
Primary graft contracture is due to elastin, more with full thickness graft

Secondary graft contracture is due to myofibroblast activity, more with split thickness skin graft.

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument?
questions.solution: The image shows power dermatome used in harvesting split thickness skin grafts.
